passages.text: The CNH bond market has been fast growing in recent years, reaching RMB1.5tn as end of Jul'25. Outside sovereign bonds and PBoC bills, foreign financial issuers (FIs) and China LGFVs have been key drivers. Rising CNH issuance from foreign FIs is mainly driven by 1) the interest rate gap between the US and China; and 2) strong demand from mainland investors amid declining yields in China onshore market. China LGFVs, on the other hand, have been active in CNH market due to tightened onshore issuance. In the recent months, CNH bonds have become topical as we see more issuance from non- financial corps outside China LGFVs. YTD, RMB32bn CNH bonds have been issued by non- financial corps (ex- China LGFVs), up \(30\%\) YoY, given the relatively low funding cost and increasing demand. For CNH corp bond issued in YTD25, on average, the CNH coupon rate is 35bp/19bp lower than comparable USD/EUR bond yields (Exhibit 9, Exhibit 10). In addition, some companies issue CNH bonds to meet RMB funding needs, like HK developers with investments in China mainland. On the demand side, it has been strong, given the attractive pick- up of CNH bond over other currencies and relaxation of Southbound Bond Connect (expanding eligible investors to China NBFCs). On a hedged basis, CNH bonds are now providing 22bp/13bp/6bp yield pick- up over CNY/EUR/USD bonds. With RMB depreciation pressure easing, we expect robust southbound inflows to lead to further compression. Within CNH universe (Exhibit 17), we find 1) HK financial and property are most attractive, while Chinese banks are most expensive, 2) HK and Singapore quasi are more attractive than China SOEs, and 3) foreign issuers' CNH bonds are cheaper than China/HK issuers with similar rating/duration.

Onshore credit bonds saw RMB778bn net supply in Jul, higher than RMB411bn in Jun. Financial bond net supply hit a record high of RMB418bn, driven by strong net supply from bank capital and security companies; non- financial net supply also increased to RMB358bn \((+42\%\) MoM). SOEs saw RMB317bn net supply, out of which LGFVs saw RMB42bn net redemption, while non- LGFV SOEs saw RMB358bn net supply. POEs saw RMB41bn net supply mainly from AAA ones, vs. net redemption of RMB37bn in Jun.

The LTM default rate by amount was unchanged at \(0.1\%\) and eased to \(0.21\%\) by count. The SOE default rate remained at the lowest end. POE default rate by amount/count dropped from \(3.7\% /5.7\%\) end of Jun'25 to \(3.2\% /5.0\%\) as end of Jul'25.

In July & MTD- Aug., offshore yields went up 10bp/8bp for IG/HY to \(2.0\% /2.1\%\) , given no more near- term policy boost. We saw divergence in the offshore market. While offshore HY yields declined 100bp to \(11\%\) , offshore IG yields rose by 4bp to \(4.7\%\) . On a currency- hedged basis, offshore IG/HY continued to offer RV vs. onshore, which is now 91bps/717bps for IG/HY. On average, yield pick- up for CNY over USD bond after hedging is \(- 1.0\%\) for SOEs, \(- 0.57\%\) for LGFVs, \(- 3.68\%\) for property, and \(- 0.46\%\) for financials.

Trading ideas and investment strategies discussed herein may give rise to significant risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should have experience in relevant markets and the financial resources to absorb any losses arising from applying these ideas or strategies. BofA Securities does and seeks to do business with issuers covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Refer to important disclosures on page 22 to 24.

Special topic of the monthThe CNH bond market has been fast growing in recent years, reaching RMB1.5tn as end of Jul'25. Outside sovereign bonds and PBoC bills, foreign financial issuers (FIs) and China LGFVs have been key drivers. Rising CNH issuance from foreign FIs is mainly driven by 1) the interest rate gap between the US and China; and 2) strong demand from mainland investors amid declining yields in China onshore market. China LGFVs, on the other hand, have been active in CNH market due to tightened onshore issuance. In the recent months, CNH bonds have become topical as we see more issuance from non- financial corps outside China LGFVs. YTD, RMB32bn CNH bonds have been issued by non- financial corps (ex- China LGFVs), up \(30\%\) YoY, given the relatively low funding cost and increasing demand. For CNH corp bond issued in YTD25, on average, the CNH coupon rate is 35bp/19bp lower than comparable USD/EUR bond yields (Exhibit 9, Exhibit 10). In addition, some companies issue CNH bonds to meet RMB funding needs, like HK developers with investments in China mainland. On the demand side, it has been strong, given the attractive pick- up of CNH bond over other currencies and relaxation of Southbound Bond Connect (expanding eligible investors to China NBFCs). On a hedged basis, CNH bonds are now providing 22bp/13bp/6bp yield pick- up over CNY/EUR/USD bonds. With RMB depreciation pressure easing, we expect robust southbound inflows to lead to further compression. Within CNH universe (Exhibit 17), we find 1) HK financial and property are most attractive, while Chinese banks are most expensive, 2) HK and Singapore quasi are more attractive than China SOEs, and 3) foreign issuers' CNH bonds are cheaper than China/HK issuers with similar rating/duration.

The CNH bond has grown strongly since 2022, the outstanding of which rose \(185\%\) from RMB0.52tn as end- 2021 to RMB1.5tn as end of Jul'25 (Exhibit 1). As Exhibit 3 shows, the issuance increased across categories over the past few years.

CNH financial bond: strong issuance from foreign issuersCNH bond issuance from the financial sector has been strong since 2022, given CNH funding cost has been much lower than USD, against the backdrop of diverging monetary policies between the US and China. As Exhibit 6 shows, CNH financial bond supply is dominated by foreign financial institutions (FIs), accounting for \(c.70\%\) of the annual issuance over the past decade. The CNH issuance from non- China FIs peaked in 2022 as the Fed started hiking while China rates declined amid policy easing, accounting for \(88\%\) of the total CNH financial bond supply. The weight normalized to \(c.70\%\) in the years following that, but the absolute amount remained above RMB100bn in 2023/24, and reached RMB96bn in 7M25 (+23% YoY). Apart from the low CNH funding cost, another key driver is the rising demand for CNH debt instruments, especially from mainland investors, given the low onshore yields.

CNH corporate bond: China LGFVs as the key playerLooking at the non- financial corporate space, China LGFV is the major issuer of CNH bond in the past few years. China LGFV has been tapping the CNH bond market since 2022, especially weak ones, as regulators tightened the onshore bond issuance to control hidden debt risk. As Exhibit 7 shows, the CNH LGFV bond issuance reached RMB189bn in 2024, then declined to RMB57bn in 7M25, down \(47\%\) YoY. The decline is primarily due to the RMB10tn debt- swapping program launched in late- 2024, and tightened Southbound Bond Connect channel to invest in CNH LGFV bonds. In our view, the peak of CNH LGFV bond issuance has passed, and the issuance will gradually decline in the following years. As end of Jul'25, the outstanding amount of CNH non- financial corp bond has reached RMB536bn, among which \(75\%\) is from China LGFV, followed by Hong Kong real estate (11%), China technology (5%), and transportation (4%).

PBoC's CNH bills as liquidity- management toolPBoC kicked off CNH bills issuance in Hong Kong in November 2018, aiming to expand high- quality RMB- denominated products in the offshore market and to enhance the CNH

yield curve at the front end. The PBoC bills are short term in nature, offering 3m, 6m, and 12m tenors. During the first few years (1H19- 1H23), the outstanding amount of PBoC CNH bills has remained largely stable, with regular and steady issuances to roll over maturing bills. Since 2H23, the issuance size started increasing, which culminated in 1Q25, when a total of RMB120bn bills being auctioned. While the larger offerings would help meet the growing investment demand for offshore RMB products, we believe that the more important policy objective was to manage CNH liquidity and maintain exchange rate stability. With FX pressure alleviated, we see less PBoC CNH bill issuance since Mar'25, with only RMB30bn issued in Jun'25. The most maturity of RMB165bn, the outstanding amount decreased to RMB80bn and end of Jul'25 from RMB215bn as end of Feb'25. See report, Asia FI & FX Strategy Viewpoint: Dissecting drivers of CNH liquidity 19 June 2025.

In September 2009, China's MoF issued its first RMB- denominated bond in the offshore market. Since then, it has made regular issuances in Hong Kong and other financial centers, which not only expanded the CNH asset pool but also supported the establishment of a CNH sovereign yield curve as a reference for non- sovereign issuers. The outstanding amount of CNH CGBs was RMB170bn as end of Jul'25, which is only a fraction of CNY CGBs (c. RMB36tn). On 28 May, the MoF announced that it will issue a total of RMB68bn RMB- denominated treasury bonds in Hong Kong in 2025, a 24% increase in gross issuance from 2024. See report, Asia FI & FX Strategy Viewpoint: Dissecting drivers of CNH liquidity 19 June 2025. The Hong Kong government has started to issue CNH bonds since 2021, and issued total RMB61bn since 2023, mainly due to the weak fiscal revenue. As our HK economist points out, Hong Kong has increasingly turned to the bond market to fund its infrastructure spending due to weaker land premium. See report, Asia FI & FX Strategy Viewpoint: HKD Debt: A feast of upcoming supply 16 April 2025.
The CNH bond outstanding reached RMB1.5tn as of end- Jul'25, \(+23\%\) YoY; CNH CD stands at RMB0.5tn; the CNH market has seen strong growth since 2022, after stagnating during 2017- 21
Source: Bloomberg, BofA Global Research

What is new in 2025In year-to-date 2025, CNH non- financial bond issuance outside China LGFVs has increased 30% YoY to RMB32bn. Cost advantage is the main driver. As Exhibit 9 and Exhibit 10 shows, incorporating currency hedging costs, the USD equivalent coupon of CNH bond is lower than comparable USD and EUR bonds. For CNH bond issued year- to- date, on average, CNH coupon rate is 35bp/19bp lower than USD/EUR bond yields. In addition, some issuers issue CNH bonds to meet their RMB funding needs, like Hong Kong developers with investments in the China mainland.

China corporateChinese companies issue CNH bonds to repay offshore debt with high interest rate and/or to fund oversea capex. As most Chinese companies (non- LGFVs, non- tech) have good access to onshore cheap CNY funding, they only tap the offshore CNH market for USD/HKD funding needs. Over the past few years, we have seen large net redemption of Chinese USD bond due to the high USD interest rate. Although onshore market is major source of funding for Chinese companies, the issuers tap the CNH bond market to keep their offshore funding channel open and to fund overseas capex.

China techFor Chinese tech companies, they issue CNH bond mainly due to cheaper CNH funding costs compared with their USD bond yields. For example, Baidu issued 5Y/10Y RMB2.5bn/RMB7.5bn CNH bonds in Mar'25 with coupon rate of \(2.7\% /3.0\%\) , which are 31bp/55bp cheaper than comparable USD bonds, incorporating currency hedging costs. We expect the trend to continue, given 1) persistent cost advantage of CNH funding versus USD, 2) USD funding needs for overseas expansion and investment in new technologies, and 3) USD/HKD needs to pay dividends and buy back shares. See report, China IG Technology: Credit & equity implications of internet firms' dim sum bond/CB/EB issuance trend 28 July 2025.

Non- China corporateFor foreign issuers, they issue CNH bonds mainly due to lower funding costs versus other currencies. For example, Danone (BNFP), a French food processing company, issued a 6Y RMB57Omn CNH bond in Jun'25 with a coupon rate of \(2.38\%\) , which is 63bp/17bp cheaper than comparable USD/EUR bonds, incorporating currency hedging costs. Given the cost advantage and the trend of RMB internationalization, we see potential of more foreign entities entering the CNH bond market.

The yield pick-up of CNH over CNY has been positive in the past few years, due to the abundant and stable RMB liquidity in the China onshore market, while offshore RMB rates are more sensitive to US rate moves. In 4Q24, the yield pick-up of CNH bond over CNY bond widened more than 50bp to c.90bp due to the tightening of CNH liquidity amid FX pressure. In year-to-date 2025, the appetite for CNH bond has been strong,given the attractive CNH-CNY yield pick-up, eased FX pressure, and the potential relaxation of Southbound Bond Connect. As a result, the yield pick-up of CNH over CNY has been narrowing, with CGB yield differential compressing from 80bp as of end-2024 to 8bp now (Exhibit 11), and from 90bp to 11bp for credit bonds (Exhibit 12). Looking forward, we believe demand for CNH bonds will remain strong, mainly supported by 1)inflows from the Southbound Bond Connect, following expansion of eligible investors under the scheme, and 2) rising participation from foreign investors given more CNH bond issuance, good market technicals, and further spread compression potential.

On July 8, the PBoC and HKMA announced to expand the eligible investors of the Southbound Bond Connect to four major types of non- bank financial institutions, including securities firms, fund managers, insurers, and wealth management institutions. Before the announcement, NBFCs can only invest in the offshore market via QDII/RQDII, and Southbound Bond Connect is limited to 41 banks (2 policy banks, 6 state commercial banks, 12 JSBs, 17 city/rural banks, 4 foreign banks).

As end of Jul'25, according to Shanghai Clearing House, bond held under Southbound Connect is RMB549bn, largely unchanged from end- 2024. The net increase in June and July is only c.RMB16bn. We think that a large part of the Southbound flows has not been reflected in the depository data, because the funds have not invested in the Hong Kong bond market. Currently, the Southbound Bond Connect is subject to a daily/annual quota of RMB20bn/RMB500bn, which is barely used year- to- date according to bond depository data. Our FX and rate strategist expects potential resumption of Southbound Bond Connect flows given easing RMB depreciation pressure. This, together with the expansion of eligible investor should bring strong inflows to Hong Kong market, serving as tailwind for CNH and USD bond market.

The pick- up of CNH over CNY yield has been positive since 2022; it peaked at 80bp as end- 2024 due to tightening of CNH liquidity amid FX pressure, then tightened to only 8bp the latest due to chase for yield demand
Source:ICE,BofA Global Research

As of end- Jul'25, bond outstanding under Southbound Bond Connect is RMB549bn according to Shanghai Clearing House, largely unchanged from end- 2024; we expect this to increase in the coming months following expansion of Southbound Bond Connect eligible investors
Source:Wind,Bloomberg,BofA Global Research
The pick- up of CNH bond yield over onshore CNY bond yield has narrowed from above c.90bp around end- 2024 amid tightening of CNH liquidity to 11bp the latest
Source:Bloomberg,BofA Global Research

Expect more foreign issuers to tap CNH bond marketAs the US-China rate differential likely to sustain, we expect more foreign issuers to enter CNH bond market for lower funding costs. From an investor perspective, this will enhance their returns, as non-China issuers usually provide higher yields than Chinese issuers (see Exhibit 17). The strong China demand from southbound should support the market well, leading to further compression. We expect a more diversified issuer structure.

We compare the current valuation across currencies and see the following. 1) CNH bonds issued by Chinese banks provide higher yields than CNY bonds, with an average CNH- CNY yield pick- up of 22bp, while CNH bonds issued by China SOEs have similar yields as CNY bonds (Exhibit 15). 2) CNH bonds of Hong Kong developers, China HY industrial, and China SOE are more attractive than their USD bonds; while for financial and tech, their USD bond yields are higher than CNH bond yields (Exhibit 14). 3) CNH bonds, on average, provide a yield pick- up of 13bp over EUR bonds, while we see mixed results for different bond pairs (Exhibit 16).

Within the CNH bond universe, among the same ratings, Hong Kong financial and Hong Kong property look most attractive, while Chinese banks are most expensive. With quasi sovereign, Hong Kong and Singapore are more attractive than China SOEs, considering rating difference. CNH bonds issued by foreign entities look cheap versus China/HK issuers. For example, NESNVX '35 is providing 7bp yield pick- up over BABA '34, 37bp pick- up over HK quasi (HKAA, MTRC), and 36bp pick- up over China A SOE. Exhibit 17

In Jul, the gross supply of credit bonds rose to RMB1.9tn, \(+8\%\) MoM. The growth was driven by financial bond \((+35\%)\) MoM to RMB615bn), while the issuance from nonfinancial corps was largely flat MoM at RMB1.3tn. However, excluding commercial paper (CP), non- financial issuance decreased by \(9\%\) MoM to RMB914bn. Government bond supply decreased by \(4\%\) MoM to RMB3.2tn, due to lower treasury issuance (RMB1.2tn, \(+23\%\) MoM), versus. high CGB issuance in the past few months (avg. RMB1.5tn during Apr- Jun).

Note: "Credit bonds" include financial bonds (excluding policy bank bonds), exchange corporate bonds, enterprise bonds, MTNs, private placement notes (PPNs), and commercial paper (CP), unless otherwise specified.

As of Jul, credit bond saw a YTD gross supply of RMB11.1tn, \(+5\%\) YoY, the highest 7M level over the past 7 years (since 2019)

YTD25 issuance is dominated by LGFVs \((23\%)\) , banking \((20\%)\) , financial services \((12\%)\) , utility \((10\%)\) and capital goods \((9\%)\) ; the weight of LGFV bonds declined from \(27\%\) in 2024 to \(23\%\) in YTD25, while that of bank bonds increased from \(17\%\) in 2024 to \(20\%\) in YTD25

In Jul, onshore credit bonds saw net supply of RMB778bn, higher than RMB411bn in Jun, driven by stronger issuance and smaller redemption. The financial bond net supply hit a record high of RMB418bn (+164% MoM), mainly due to strong net supply from bank capital and security companies. Non- financial bond's net supply also increased 42% MoM to RMB358bn. Within non- financial, SOEs saw RMB317bn net supply, out of which LGFVs still saw net redemption of RMB42bn (vs. RMB69bn net redemption in Jun), while non- LGFV SOEs had RMB358bn net supply (similar as that in Jun). POEs saw net supply of RMB41bn mainly from AAA- rated ones, vs. net redemption of RMB37bn in Jun. Onshore property bonds saw RMB5.4bn net supply, lower than RMB15.2bn in Jun.

In 7M25, onshore credit bonds net supply reached RMB2.3tn (+12% YoY), driven by financial but partially offset by weaker non- financial. Specifically, financial bonds saw YTD net supply of RMB971bn (+59% YoY), while non- financial credit bond YTD net supply decreased 8% YoY to RMB1.4tn. Within non- financials, SOEs saw YTD net supply of RMB1.3tn (- 13% YoY), due to higher net redemption from LGFVs (RMB335bn in 7M25 vs. RMB155bn in 7M24), while non- LGFV SOEs net supply was largely unchanged YoY at RMB1.6tn. POEs saw stronger YTD net supply of RMB86bn (vs. RMB6bn in 7M24), majority of which came from AAA- rated POEs, and non- AAA ones also saw positive net supply vs. net redemption in the previous year. Property bonds saw net redemption of RMB14bn in 7M25, versus RMB34bn net redemption in 7M24.

In Jul, the 5yr CGB yield increased by 5bp from 1.52% as of end- Jun to 1.57% as of end- Jul. Meanwhile, credit yields declined for lower rated bonds (AA or below) but edged up 2- 6bp for AAA and AA+ rated bond. As a result, credit spread was largely unchanged for higher- rated bond and tightened for lower- rated ones. In MTD- Aug (as of 26th Aug), the 5yr CGB yield increased another 5bp to 1.62%, and credit yields widened in general, more for higher rating. Because credit yields went up more for enterprise bond than corporate bond, credit spreads widened 1- 5bp for enterprise bond in MTD- Aug but tightened 1- 6bp for corporate bond.

In July, onshore yields went up for both IG and HY, while we saw diverging trend in the offshore market. Onshore IG/HY yields went up 4bp/2bp to \(1.93\% /2.01\%\) . In the offshore market, IG yields \(+7bp\) to \(4.73\%\) , while offshore HY yields went down 64bp to \(11.40\%\) . In MTD- Aug (as of \(26^{\text{th}}\) Aug), we saw divergence between onshore and offshore yields. Onshore IG/HY yields further went up 6bp each to \(1.99\% /2.07\%\) , and offshore IG/HY yields dropped 3bp/36bp to \(4.70\% /11.04\%\) . Since Jul, onshore yields edged up from a low level, as policy makers struck a balance tone in the end- Jul Politburo meeting, offering little scope for major stimulus measures. Our China economists now expect no more rate cut by end- 2026, see report, China Watch: July Politburo meeting: no more near- term policy boost in sight 30 July 2025.

On a currency- hedge basis, both offshore IG and HY still offer relative value (RV) vs. their onshore peers. The hedged RV of offshore yields over onshore widened 16bp to 91bp for IG due to lower hedging factor, but tightened 80bp to 717bp for HY in Jul and MTD- Aug,

On a bond- to- bond basis, we compare onshore bond yields with corresponding USD bond yields with similar maturities, after factoring in hedging costs from major issuers of SOE, LGFV, property and financial sectors. Consistent with what we see on an aggregate basis, after hedging, USD bonds are still cheaper than CNY bonds. Currently, on average, the pick- up in yield for CNY bonds over USD bonds after hedging is \(- 1.00\%\) for SOEs, \(- 0.57\%\) for LGFVs, \(- 3.68\%\) for property sector, and \(- 0.46\%\) for financials. For details, see Appendix: Relative value analysis.

In July, we saw no hard default. The LTM default rate by amount remained largely unchanged at \(0.08\%\) , while edged down to \(0.21\%\) from \(0.24\%\) by count. By company type, the SOE default rate by amount/count was unchanged at \(0.03\% /0\%\) , the lowest end. POE default rate by amount/count dropped from \(3.7\% /5.7\%\) as end of Jun'25 to \(3.2\% /5.0\%\) as end of Jul'25. For the property sector, the LTM default rate by amount/count remained largely unchanged at \(0.9\% /1.2\%\) .

Note that the above default rate is based on Wind's definition, i.e., hard default cases excluding payment extension. If we include payment extension into the calculation, the LTM default rate by amount would be \(0.14\%\) for the overall HY (non- AAA) onshore market, \(0.02\%\) for SOEs, and \(5.3\%\) for POEs. Specifically for the property sector, the LTM default rate by amount/count would be \(3.8\% /4.7\%\) . For private developers alone, the LTM default rate by amount/count would be \(8.6\% /11.8\%\) .

In August, we expect RMB900bn of credit bonds (excluding financial bonds) to mature (including RMB550bn from CPs), higher than RMB809bn in July. A breakdown by sector shows LGFVs (38%), utility (20%), basic industry (10%), and capital goods (9%) as the major sectors with bonds due in Aug.
August maturity will increase to RMB900bn from RMB809bn in July

The amount of bonds becoming puttable in August will be RMB218bn, more than RMB193bn in July. For August puttable bonds, LGFVs should remain the largest sector, accounting for \(61\%\) of the total puttable amount, followed by capital goods (9%), basic industry (7%), and services (6%). For puttable bonds in July, \(75\%\) of bonds by amount were put back, vs. \(70\%\) in the previous month. The average coupon rate changes after the put date came in at - 118bp vs. - 123bp in the previous month.
